clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Autonomic Dynamic Dysfunction to Predict Infections After Spinal Cord Injury.
clinical_study.official_title: PROSPECT ADDITION SCI - A PROSPECTive Study of Autonomic Dynamic Dysfunction to Predict infecTIONs After Spinal Cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock: The study is designed to investigate whether autonomic shifts (dysautonomia, sympatho-vagal instability) that develop after SCI have value in predicting SCI-associated infections (SCI-AI). SCI-AI impair outcomes by (1) reducing the intrinsic neurological recovery potential and (2) increasing mortality. Heart Rate Variability (HRV) data will be tracked in both the time and frequency domains to discriminate between the relative contribution of sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation to changes in HRV. The ability to predict infections will enable novel treatments thereby reducing infection-associated mortality and improving neurological and functional outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: Sympatho-vagal instability as an identifier for patients at risk for Spinal Cord Injury Associated Infections
primary_outcome.time_frame: At all study time-points for a period of 24hours.
primary_outcome.description: Determining whether discrete signs of loss of autonomic control (dysautonomia), not meeting defined criteria of full-autonomic dysreflexia, also renders patients "at risk" for developing infections.

arm_group.description: Observational study - monitoring immune response and heart rate variability
Observational study - monitoring immune response and heart rate variability acting as a control group.

study_pop.textblock: Based on historical data of acute SCI patients admitted to OSU, we estimate enrollment of approximately 16 SCI patients per year to meet eligibility criteria. Consequently, a recruitment period of 36 months is scheduled to meet the anticipated need of n=50 subjects. There are more than 60 isolated vertebra fractures being surgically stabilized per year at OSU (personal communication, Dr David Evans, Traumatology, OSU). Based on the asymmetric recruitment populations we expect to complete the non-SCI referent cohort (n=10) earlier than the SCI cohort. The referent cohort will have sustained a vertebral fracture without myelopathy and will have undergone spine surgery, anesthesia and subsequent monitoring in the ICU. Investigators will evaluate patients after admission to the emergency ward for eligibility (Table 3). Before final inclusion into the study an interview will be conducted with the patient to verify the inclusion- and exclusion criteria and obtain written informed consent.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Isolated traumatic SCI (ASIA A-D), surgical stabilization planned/performed, a singular lesion (lesion can include more than one segment)
- Isolated spinal fracture without neurological abnormality (ASIA E) surgical stabilization planned/performed
- Legal age of the patient (18)
- Ability to give informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-traumatic SCI
- 2 or more spinal cord lesions definable from one another
- Polytrauma*
- Additional severe traumatic brain injury (TBI)*
- Neoplasia and/or antineoplastic therapy
- Rheumatic diseases / collagenosis / vasculitis
- Other autoimmune diseases
- Pre-existing acute/chronic infection
- Pre-existing systemic steroid treatment (except NASCIS)
- Severe alcohol or drug addiction
